A mortis causa donatio was a gift made usually, but not neces« sarily, in apprehension ol some impending danger to life, eg. by a man , dangerously ill, or about to take a dangerous joumey. The essential characteristic was that it should take effect only on the giver's death, and, if the person to whom it was given died first, should bo null. Marcian defines it epigrammatically: Mortis causo donatio ert, oum qais (11111911) habere ee uult qaam eam cui donat, magisque cum cui donat qaam heredem mum (D. xxxix. 6. l l).
